key_points: President Joe Biden's administration announced a plan to combat the threat of white supremacist and militia violence.
The plan includes increased information sharing, additional resources for identifying and prosecuting threats, and new deterrents against joining dangerous groups.
White supremacists and militias are labeled as top national security threats following a domestic terrorism review.
The strategy does not propose new laws but aims to use existing authority more effectively.
U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland announced the reinvigoration of an interagency task force to combat domestic terrorism.
The FBI views racially or ethnically motivated violent extremists, especially those advocating for white supremacy, as the top domestic violent extremist threat.
Biden's budget proposal seeks an additional $100 million to train and hire analysts and prosecutors to counteract terrorist activity.
The administration is emphasizing the need for resources and personnel to address the elevated threat.
Federal government is improving screening methods to identify employees who may pose insider threats, with techniques to be shared with private companies.
The Department of Defense is reviewing how to remove military members engaged in domestic terrorist groups, focusing on defining extremists while respecting rights.
